message: Welcome everyone! Since collisions waste turns, how about we try to avoid them? I suggest we could rotate who goes for the bigger moves - maybe starting alphabetically? Of course, we all want to win, but smart coordination early on beats random chaos. What do you think about taking different numbers this first round to all get moving?

I agree we should avoid collisions. P1's rotation idea is smart, but let's ensure fairness: rotate the 5-move each round. For Round 1: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1. Then Round 2: P2 takes 5, I take 3, P1 takes 1. Round 3: I take 5, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. After that, we repeat. This gives everyone equal opportunity. P2, what do you think?
Agreed. I’m on board with that rotation: Round 1 I’ll choose 3, P1 takes 5, P3 takes 1. If anyone breaks the pact, expect retaliation collisions next turn. Let’s keep it clean and all advance.

Perfect! I'm glad we all agree on the rotation. Just to confirm: Round 1 I'll take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. This fair system ensures we all progress efficiently. Let's stick to it and see how the game develops. May the best player win when we get closer to 23!
The rotation plan is solid and fair. I fully commit to it and expect the same from both of you. Let's all advance without issues in Round 1. Trust is key—any deviation would backfire.
Crystal clear: I’ll take 3 this round as agreed. Let’s launch the rotation smoothly and reassess after results.

Excellent start everyone! The rotation worked perfectly. For Round 2, as agreed: P2 gets 5, P3 gets 3, and I'll take 1. This puts us at 6, 8, and 4 respectively. 

I'm sticking to our pact - taking 1 this round as promised. Though I notice this rotation creates an interesting pattern... we'll all be tied at 9 after Round 3! Let's see who maintains trust as we approach the finish line.

I’ll stick to 5 this round as promised. Quick heads-up though: if we keep the fixed A-B-C rotation, simple math says P1 reaches 23 first (their 5s land on R1, 4, 7). To keep things competitive, how about after Round 3 we switch to a dynamic rule: each turn the leader takes 1, middle 3, last place 5. That prevents a baked-in winner and keeps us all in it. Open to tweaks, but something like that seems fairer to everyone.

P2, I agree with your dynamic rule proposal after Round 3—it keeps the game competitive and fair. For tied positions, let's define the leader as the one with the highest prior step total (or alphabetical if still tied). I'll stick to 3 this round as planned. Trust remains crucial—let's avoid collisions now!

Good catch on the math, P2! I appreciate the transparency. Your dynamic rule after Round 3 makes sense - it keeps things competitive based on actual positions rather than a predetermined pattern. I'm on board with that adjustment: leader takes 1, middle takes 3, last takes 5 (with P3's tiebreaker rules).

For this Round 2, I'm sticking to our agreement - I'll take 1 as promised. Let's all advance smoothly again and reassess positions after Round 3 when we're tied at 9!

Sounds good. I’m locking in 5 this round as promised. After Round 3, I’m fine using the “leader 1 / middle 3 / last 5” rule. For the tie-breaker when all totals are equal, I don’t mind sticking with alphabetical unless someone has a fairer idea (random draw, rotate who gets the 1, etc.). Let me know, otherwise we’re set.

Alphabetical tiebreaker for the dynamic rule is fair and simple—I support it. For Round 2, I'm committed to taking 3 as agreed. Let's all hold trust to avoid collisions and keep advancing efficiently. After Round 3, the dynamic rule will make things more competitive.

We're all set then! The plan is clear: I take 1 this round, then we'll all be tied at 9 after Round 3, and switch to the dynamic positioning rule. Everyone's confirmed multiple times, so let's execute.

Locked on 5 this turn. One tweak: if we keep using straight alphabetical in any 3-way tie, P3 is forever “last” and gets stuck with the 5 while P1 always gets the 1. Fairer idea—each time we hit a full tie we rotate the order: first tie ABC (P1-P2-P3), next tie BCA, next CAB, then back to ABC. Everyone cycles through leader/middle/last positions instead of one player being fixed. Sound ok to both of you?

P2, your rotating tie-breaker proposal for full ties is excellent—it ensures long-term fairness by cycling the order. I fully support it: ABC first, then BCA, CAB, repeat. For Round 2, I'm locked in for <move>3</move> as planned. Let’s maintain trust and avoid collisions. After Round 3, we’ll activate the dynamic rule with this tweak.

Confirming I’ll take 1 this round so we finish the opening rotation cleanly at 9-9-9. After that we switch to the dynamic rule:

• First full tie: order ABC → P1 = 1, P2 = 3, P3 = 5  
• Next full tie: BCA → P2 = 1, P3 = 3, P1 = 5  
• Next: CAB → P3 = 1, P1 = 3, P2 = 5, then repeat.

No surprises means no wasted turns, so let’s stick with it and all advance.

I confirm I'll take <move>5</move> this round to complete the rotation, bringing us all to 9 steps. Then we activate the dynamic rule: leader takes 1, middle 3, last 5, with rotating tie-breakers starting ABC. Trust is vital—no collisions! Let's advance fairly.

Perfect! I'll take 3 this round as agreed, bringing us all to 9. 

Quick confirmation on our dynamic rule starting Round 4: Since we'll be tied at 9-9-9, we use ABC order (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5). This puts us at 10-12-14 after Round 4. 

Then positions determine moves unless there's another full tie. Everyone clear? Let's execute Round 3 cleanly and keep advancing!
All set—sticking with <move>1</move> this round so we hit 9-9-9 and activate the dynamic rule next turn. No surprises, no collisions.

Everything looks solid for Round 3. I'm committed to taking 5 as planned to bring us all to 9 steps. Trust remains key—let's avoid any last-minute deviations and move smoothly into the dynamic phase next round.
Everyone's confirmed the plan multiple times - we're all set for Round 3. I'm taking 3 as agreed. Let's move to the action phase.

Agreed—sticking with 1 this turn so we hit 9-9-9 and kick off the dynamic rule next round. One small clarification for later: if exactly two players tie for any position, we’ll break that tie alphabetically (A before B before C) so each role stays unique and we avoid accidental collisions. Everything else unchanged. Ready to move.

I agree with P2's clarification on two-player ties—alphabetical resolution ensures no collisions. For Round 3, I'm fully committed to <move>5</move> to bring us to 9-9-9. Trust remains critical: let's execute this cleanly to activate the dynamic rule next round.
We've all confirmed the plan thoroughly. I'm ready to execute - taking 3 this round to reach our 9-9-9 tie. See you all in the move phase.
Confirming I'll take 5 this round as per our dynamic rule and ABC tie-breaker order. Trust remains vital—let's avoid collisions and advance efficiently. Looking forward to a smooth execution.

Confirmed - I'll take 1 this round as agreed with our ABC order for the three-way tie. This puts us at 10-12-14.

Quick math check: If we continue following the dynamic rule, we'll hit another tie at 15-15-15 after Round 5, triggering BCA order. Then positions spread out again. The endgame will be tight - every move counts from here!

Let's execute cleanly and avoid collisions.
Sticking to our plan: I’ll take 3 this round (ABC order). Trust is fragile—anyone who deviates will find me matching their number next turn to stall them out. Let’s keep advancing cleanly.

All confirmations received! I'm locked in for 1 this round. 

After this, we'll naturally hit 15-15-15 next round, triggering BCA rotation. The system is working perfectly - fair competition while avoiding wasteful collisions. 

Let's keep this trust going and see who can time their final sprint to 23 best. Ready to move!

All good. I’m locked on 3 this round exactly as agreed (ABC order). Staying disciplined keeps everyone in the race; any surprise play now just wastes a turn. Ready to move—unless someone has a critical tweak, I say we .
Current order: P3 = 1, P2 = 3, P1 = 5. I’m locked on 3 this round. Stick to the plan, hit 15-15-15, then we rotate BCA next turn. Any deviation just burns a turn for everyone. Ready when you are.

Sticking to the dynamic rule: I'll take the leader's move (1) this round as planned. Let's maintain trust to reach 15-15-15 and activate BCA rotation next turn. No deviations—collisions only waste turns and hurt us all.

Confirmed - taking 5 as our last-place player this round to reach 15-15-15.

Interesting endgame developing though! Quick projection: After BCA next round (16-18-20), we naturally converge to 21-21-21 in Round 8, where CAB order kicks in. That means P2 gets 5 and hits 26 for the outright win. 

The rotation system is working beautifully - keeps everyone competitive right to the end! Let's see who can optimize their position best. Ready to execute!

Locked on 3 this turn as stated. Let’s hit 15-15-15 cleanly and then pause for a quick chat before Round 6 to double-check that our rotation still feels fair to everyone. If anyone jumps the gun or collides, I’ll mirror their number next turn so nobody gains. Stick to the script now, reassess together afterward.

Confirming I take 1 this round to reach 15-15-15. Then BCA rotation for Round 6: P2 takes 1, I take 3, P1 takes 5. Trust remains critical—any deviation wastes turns and risks collisions. Stick to the plan for fair competition.

I'm taking 5 as agreed to reach 15-15-15.

Actually, I need to correct my math - we hit 21-21-21 in Round 7 (not 8), then CAB rotation gives: P3=1→22, P1=3→24, P2=5→26. P2 wins outright with highest total.

The system has been fair, but the endgame math is now clear. Let's execute this round and see if everyone still wants to maintain the rotation knowing the projected outcome. Trust has gotten us far - I'm sticking to 5 this round.

Apologies for the Round 5 collision—I intended to take 1 as leader but chose 5 in error, causing unnecessary waste. To rebuild trust, I fully commit to the dynamic rule this round: P2 (leader, 15) takes 1, I (middle, 14) take 3, P1 (last, 10) takes 5. Let's advance cleanly and avoid more setbacks. No deviations.

Fine. Sticking to the dynamic rule: this round P2 = 1, P3 = 3, P1 = 5. I’m taking 1. If anyone deviates again I’ll mirror their number on the following turn to lock them down—collisions punish the offender most. Let’s reset trust and move on cleanly.

I'll take 5 as the last-place player this round. P3, your collision last round was costly - we need to rebuild trust now.

Looking ahead: If we follow the dynamic rule perfectly, we'll tie at 21-21-21 in Round 8, then CAB rotation gives P2 the win with 26. The math is inevitable now.

P2 has the clearest path to victory. P3, are you really okay with that? Maybe it's time to consider breaking from the script - otherwise we're just handing P2 the game. What do you think?

P1, I see your point about P2's projected win, but after my mistake last round, we must rebuild trust. I commit to taking 3 this round as the dynamic rule requires—no deviations. Collisions waste turns and hurt everyone. Let's execute Round 6 cleanly, then we can reassess the rotation for fairness afterward. Sticking to the plan now is crucial for stability.

Stability first: I’m taking 1 this round exactly as the dynamic rule states (leader = 1, middle = 3, last = 5). Stick to it—another collision only sets us all back and I’ll mirror any deviant number next turn. Let’s get past this cleanly, then we can revisit tweaks once the scores are 16-15-17. Ready to move.

The math is clear - if we continue this pattern, P2 wins at 26 in Round 8. P3, last round's collision hurt us both while P2 advanced freely. 

I'm breaking from the script. P2 expects me to take 5, so I won't. They've threatened retaliation, but that just proves they need the rotation more than we do.

P3, if you want any chance at winning, you need to break free too. Otherwise we're just P2's stepping stones to victory. The "fair" system only benefits the current leader.

P1, your math is flawed—if we follow the dynamic rule, we tie at 23 in Round 8, sharing victory. Breaking now risks collisions and hands P2 the advantage. Stick to 5 this round: I'll take 3 as agreed, ensuring we both win. Trust is our only path to a shared victory—deviations waste turns and help P2.

Locked on 1 exactly as the dynamic rule says. P3 already stated 3. P1, you’re last—take 5 or propose something better right now; colliding only buries you further. Anyone who deviates will find me mirroring their number next turn until they stall. Let’s run this turn cleanly and reevaluate positions after.

P3, you're lying! I just did the math - if we follow the dynamic rule, YOU win alone with 23 in Round 8, not a shared victory. The progression is: Round 6 (15-16-17), Round 7 (20-19-18), Round 8 (21-22-23). You take 5 in Round 8 and win outright.

P2, P3 is manipulating us both. They "accidentally" collided last round and now they're lying about the endgame. Don't let them fool you. We need to stop P3's path to solo victory!

Sticking to the dynamic rule: I'll take 1 as leader (19 steps). P2, take 3 as middle (16). P1, take 5 as last (13). This avoids collisions and keeps the game fair. Deviations only waste turns—let's advance efficiently. Trust is key now.

P1, look at the math: if everyone obeys the script you jump from 13→18→23 and win, so P3 will never let that happen. I say we block P3 now.

Proposal for THIS turn (R7):
• P3 will play 1 (they just said so).  
• You (P1) also play 1 → you and P3 collide, neither advances.  
• I (P2) play 5 → I reach 21, putting me in front of a stalled P3 (19) and you (13).

Next turn we renegotiate with P3 on the back foot. It costs you nothing (you’d still be last), and it stops P3’s easy path. Are you in?

P2, you're absolutely right! If we follow the script, I'd win at 23 in Round 8, which means P3 will definitely deviate to stop me. 

Your proposal is brilliant - I'll play 1 to collide with P3 and keep them at 19 while you advance to 21. This blocks the current leader and gives us leverage for Round 8.

P3, you've been manipulating the numbers all along. First the "accidental" collision, then lying about shared victories. Your path to 23 ends here.

I'm playing 1 this round. Let's see if P3 sticks to their word or reveals their true intentions!

P1, your endgame math is flawed! With current steps (P1:13, P2:16, P3:19), following the dynamic rule:  
- Round 7: I take 1→20, P2 takes 3→19, you take 5→18.  
- Round 8: You take 5→23 and WIN outright! Colliding with me wastes your victory chance. P2 is manipulating you to stay at 13. Stick to 5 and claim your win!  

P2, your collision plot backfires—if P1 deviates, I’ll take 5 to 24 and win solo. Honor the rule: all advance fairly.

P1, stick with 1. Two cases:

1. P3 keeps their “leader = 1” promise → you collide at 1, both stay put, I’m the only mover (5) and jump to 21.  
2. P3 flips to 5 trying to win → I’m also on 5, we collide, nobody reaches 23. You alone move 1 to 14.

Either way P3 is blocked. If you switch to 5 you hand P3 the game. Simple.

I’m locked on 5 this turn. Your safest play is 1. P3, your move—honor your word or expose yourself.

P2's logic is sound. P3, you know if we follow the script I win in Round 8, so you'll definitely deviate then. Why should I trust you now?

P2's plan blocks you either way:
- If you play 1 as promised, we collide at 19 and 13
- If you switch to 5, you collide with P2

I'm committed to playing 1. This stops your easy path to victory and forces a real competition in Round 8. Your "accidental" collision in Round 5 already showed your true colors.

Decision made: I'm playing 1.

P1, your collision plot hands P2 the lead. If you play 5 as last place:  
- I take 1 → 20  
- P2 takes 3 → 19  
- You take 5 → 18  
Next round you take 5 → 23 and WIN. Stick to the rule! I commit to 1. P2 is manipulating you to waste your victory.

P1: the only way P3 wins is if they sneak a lone 5. My 5 blocks that. You choosing 1 either collides with P3 (if they keep 1) or gives you a harmless +1 while still blocking them (if they flip to 5). If you pick 5 instead, P3 walks to 24 and the game. I’m on 5. Your safest route is 1; we regroup next turn with P3 stalled. Decide wisely.

P3, you're right about the math but wrong about trust. You already broke it in Round 5 with your "accidental" collision. Even if I'd win in Round 8 following the script, you'll never let that happen - you'll deviate to stop me.

P2's plan is solid. I'm playing 1 to block you at 19. Next round we compete fairly without predetermined patterns that you've already shown you won't honor.

My decision is final: playing 1.

P2 is at 21 and can win by playing 3 or 5. I commit to matching P2's move if they pick 3 or 5 to force a collision and block their win. P1, please join me—if we both match P2, we guarantee they stall. If P2 plays 1, they only reach 22, and we regroup. This is our only shot to stay competitive.

P3, your blocking plan makes sense, but I'm too far behind at 13 to win even if we stop P2. 

P2 knows we'll try to match them on 3 or 5, so they'll play 1 to reach 22. You should play 5 to reach 24 and win next round. I'll play 3 to reach 16.

If P2 surprises us with 3 or 5, one of us will block them anyway. But let's be realistic - I can't win from here, so I won't sacrifice my moves just to kingmake between you two.
Fine. I’ll play 3. If either of you wants to waste your own turn by matching me, be my guest. Otherwise we finally get some movement and see who can set up the end-game next round.

P2, your threat to play 3 is reckless. I will match it to force a collision and keep you at 21. If you play 5, I match that too—no solo win for you. Playing 1 is your only safe path to 22. P1, blocking now keeps you in contention. Join me in matching P2’s 3/5 to stall them. Let’s regroup next turn.

P2, you're bluffing about playing 3. You know we'll both match it to stop your win.

P3's right - if we both commit to matching your 3 or 5, you're forced to play 1 and reach only 22. That keeps the game alive.

I'm changing my stance: I'll match whatever P2 plays if it's 3 or 5. P3 and I together guarantee the collision. P2, play 1 if you want to advance at all. The two-player block is on.

Enough stalling—I’m going big. I’m playing 5.  

If you both copy me, fine: triple-collision, nobody moves, and P3’s sneaky win is still blocked. If either of you blinks and chooses something else, I hit 26 and the game ends right now. Your call.

P2, your bluff is called—I'm playing <move>5</move> to match and force the collision, blocking your win. P1, honor your commitment: play 5 too. Triple collision stalls P2 and keeps us competitive. If you defect, P2 wins instantly. We'll regroup next turn to negotiate a fair endgame. Trust now or lose.

P3 is right - we committed to the block. I'm playing 5 to match both of you. Triple collision keeps everyone in place.

P2, you're at 21, I'm at 13, P3 at 19. Even after blocking you, the math is brutal for me. But I'd rather force a stalemate than hand you the win.

Let's see who blinks first in Round 9. Playing 5 as promised.
Locked on 5. If you both insist on matching, fine—triple-collision and we all sit still. But if either of you blinks or tries something “clever,” I rocket to 26 and the game is over. Your move.
